Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Carnegie Mellon University is adding three new cohorts to its existing Scholarship for Service (SFS) program. Carnegie Mellon has earned an international reputation for its expertise and capability in information assurance research and education. The university's CyLab draws on the largest pool of academic cyber security researchers in the nation and combines top-ranked programs in computer science, computer engineering, software engineering, human-computer interaction, privacy technology and law, and policy.

SFS scholarships are awarded to students in either of two master's degree programs: the MS in Information Security Technology and Management and the MS in Information Security Policy and Management. Carnegie Mellon proposes to add a third master's degree program - the Pittsburgh-Silicon Valley MS in Information Technology and Information Security. The curricula of these programs have been certified pursuant to the Information Assurance Courseware Evaluation Process of the National Security Agency's CNSS 4011 - National Training Standard for Information Systems Security (INFOSEC) Professionals and CNSS 4014 - Information Assurance Training Standard for Information Systems Security Officers.

Carnegie Mellon University has been an active and enthusiastic participant in the SFS program since the program's inception. To date, 104 highly qualified students have graduated from the program, have been placed into federal information assurance positions, and make substantial contributions to the efforts of securing the Federal Government's cyberspace.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through its participation in the federal CyberCorps® Scholarship for Service (SFS) program, Carnegie Mellon University (CMU) is committed to strengthening and defending our nation’s critical information infrastructure. SFS students at CMU have access to leading educational programs in information assurance as well as hands-on learning through campus research in engineering and computer science. This report describes the university’s dedication to SFS, which includes enhanced recruitment efforts, involvement of faculty and students in research, and exposure of students to a rich variety of federal job opportunities.

 

Intellectual Merit

Under this award, CMU was able to fund 42 full-time equivalent students. CMU students in the SFS program are enrolled in the College of Engineering’s Information Networking Institute (INI) or the H. John Heinz III College (HNZ); both top-ranked schools. Through these programs, CMU strives to provide interdisciplinary studies that integrate management and policy issues with rigorous technical curriculum.

 

The SFS scholars receive opportunities for hands-on, project-based learning at CMU. They are exposed to cutting-edge research through Carnegie Mellon CyLab, a world leader in technological research. CyLab faculty are directly involved in teaching core courses that SFS students take as part of their core program requirements. Some elect to complete a master's thesis under the supervision of CyLab faculty in order to fulfill their degree requirements. Additionally, the SFS program at Carnegie Mellon requires students to take an ethics course as part of their curriculum.

 

During the fall 2014 semester, the INI began offering a Cyber Operations concentration for students enrolled in the M.S. in Information Security (MSIS) program at Carnegie Mellon. The INI also offers a Cyber Forensics and Incident Response (CyFIR) track that teaches students in the cybersecurity field how to conduct forensically sound digital investigations. Instructors from the CERT Division of the Software Engineering Institute (SEI), a leader in Internet security expertise, teach coursework in this track. Many SFS students elect to take at least one, if not all, of the courses offered in the CyFIR Track.

 

Broader Impact

In order to attract a diverse group of talented U.S. applicants, the INI admissions staff spends significant time traveling to meet with undergraduate students and to build relationships with undergraduate faculty advisors at other universities.

 

Several efforts have been established in order to attract minorities and women to Carnegie Mellon’s graduate programs. Since 2006, the INI has actively supported the recruitment of women through its sponsorship of the Grace Hopper Celebration of Women in Computing (GHC), the world’s largest gathering of women technologists, and by developing a rapport with the leadership of the Executive Women’s Forum, an annual conference for leaders in the areas of information security, risk management and privacy. Additionally, the INI plans recruitment visits and information sessions at Minority-Serving Institutions (MSI). These specific events, as well as personalized communication strategies and subsequent word-of-mouth marketing, have led to an increase in applications from minority and female applicants.
